scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-436 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-436 is a star with 0.73 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.7 times its radius. It is located 1920.63 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-436 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-436 system


Kepler-436 b

Kepler-436 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2015-02, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.34 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-436 b is 7.918 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-436 b is 2.730 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-436 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-436 c

Kepler-436 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2016-05, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-436 c is 6.042 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-436 c is 2.330 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-436 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-436, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-436 - System With 2 Exoplanets
